ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about some of the culture of China, as well as how to speak and write Chinese more proficiently.
Great course. Greatly improved all of my Chinese skills.

I improved my ability to write, speak, read, and listen to Chinese, and I am now able to form and understand a larger variety of sentences in Chinese. I also have learned more about elements of Chinese culture and history.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
This is a great and extremely well designed course, Ive been so impressed!! I have very few suggestions for improvement  the only minor points are:

1. Sometimes the English language options in multiple choice questions are ambiguous, I think more could be taken in ensuring that these are clear. 

2. The workload could be lessened slightly without compromising learning  allowing English language prompts for presentations, not having to record presentations, fewer presentations in general etc.  

3. Idont think the pre class quizzes add much value either  I completed many of them without actually learning the covered material, just finding the words and phrases I needed to in the textbook. I think getting rid of this would have 0 impact on how much people actually learn, while reducing the workload and number of assignments in a very assignment intensive course.
Sometimes some of the speeds of certain subjects (like directions) were too fast compared to other things, which made it hard to know how to learn those structures.
There has been a lot of thought and effort put into the Chinese department at Yale, and it definitely shows in the quality of teaching and the amount of material that is covered.
Structure and contents very very very good. Sometimes, the course a little bit too fast-paced

A strength of this course is definitely the organization of the course, so no assignments take you by surprise and you know when exams and assignments are coming up. Another strength of the course are the professors who are very kind, supportive, and invested in your learning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely!!! Its just so well taught, you make so much progress, its great.
Yes, if you want to learn Chinese, this teaches you a great deal.
I would. Although I have only taken two semesters I have learned quite a lot. My experience with the professors has been very good, and my friends in other sections feel the same.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Even though it is a lot of work and learning Chinese is challenging, the types of assignments are pretty straightforward, the professors are amazing, and if you keep up with the schedule the presentations/exams aren't the worst. This class certainly is not a "gut" by any means, but I never dreaded going to class, and since language classes meet every day, I feel that taking Chinese was well worth it.
